translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Discussion with Vasettha
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe
translated: Once the Lord was staying at Icchānangala, in the Icchānangala jungle-thicket.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā icchānaṅgale paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulāḥ abhiññātāḥ abhiññātāḥ brāhmaṇa mahā sālāḥ icchānaṅgale paṭivasanti
translated: Now at that time a number of well-known and famous brahmins were staying at Icchānangala,

original: caṅkī brāhmaṇo, tārukkho brāhmaṇo, pokkharasāti brāhmaṇo, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo, todeyyo brāhmaṇo, aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā.
analyzed: caṅkī brāhmaṇo tārukkhaḥ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti brāhmaṇaḥ jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo todeyyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇa mahāsālā
translated: such as the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jānussoni, Todeyya, and other well-known and famous brahmins.

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānaṁ māṇavānaṁ jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamantānaṁ anuvicarantānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭha bhāradvājānam māṇavānam jaṅghāvihāram anucaṅkamantānam anuvicarantānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: Then, as Vasettha and Bharadvaja were walking and wandering for exercise, this discussion arose between them:
“How does one become a brahmin?”
The brahmin student Bharadvaja said:

original: “yato kho, bho, ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca saṁsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena,
analyzed: yatas kho bho ubhatas sujātaḥ hoti mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca sa suddha gahaṇikaḥ yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā akkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena
translated: “When a man is well-born on both his mother’s and his father’s side, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unassailable and impeccable in respect of birth,

analyzed: ettāvatā khalu bho brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: That’s how far a brahmin can go.”
The student Vasettha said,

original: “yato kho, bho, sīlavā ca hoti vatasampanno ca,
analyzed: yatas kho bho sīlavā ca hoti vata sampanno ca
translated: “When someone is virtuous and has good conduct,

analyzed: ettāvatā khalu bho brāhmaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: that’s how far a brahmin can go.”

original: Neva kho asakkhi bhāradvājo māṇavo vāseṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ saññāpetuṁ, na pana asakkhi vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṁ māṇavaṁ saññāpetuṁ.
analyzed: na iva kho asakkhi bhāradvājaḥ māṇavaḥ vāseṭṭham māṇavam saññāpetu na pana asakkhi vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhāradvājam māṇavam saññāpetu
translated: But neither was able to convince the other.

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhāradvājam māṇavam āmantesi
translated: Then Vasettha said to Bhāradvāja,

original: “ayaṁ kho, bho bhāradvāja, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe;
analyzed: ayam kho bho bhāradvāja samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sakya putto sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe
translated: “Sir, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying in Icchānaṅgala, in the Icchānaṅgala jungle thicket.

original: taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam kha pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: And this good report about him has spread:

analyzed: iti pi pe buddhaḥ bhagavān ati
translated: ‘Such is he, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.’

original: Āyāma, bho bhāradvāja, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ etamatthaṁ pucchissāma.
analyzed: āyāma bho bhāradvāja yena samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ tena upasaṅkamissāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā samaṇam gotamam etam attham pucchissāma
translated: Come, sir, let’s go to the ascetic Gotama and ask him about this matter.

original: Yathā no samaṇo gotamo byākarissati tathā naṁ dhāressāmā”ti.
analyzed: yathā naḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ byākarissati tathā nam dhāressāma ati
translated: We will remember it as the ascetic Gotama explains it.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho bhāradvājo māṇavo vāseṭṭhassa māṇavassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho bhāradvājaḥ māṇavaḥ vāseṭṭhassa māṇavassa paccassosi
translated: “Yes, sir,” replied Bhāradvāja.

original: Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu.🔽Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
analyzed: atha khalu vāseṭṭha bhāradvājāḥ māṇavāḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodisu  sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam
translated: Then Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.🔽When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho vāseṭṭhaḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavantam gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi
translated: and Vāseṭṭha recited these verses to the Buddha:
“We’ve been approved and acknowledged
as masters of the three Vedas.

analyzed: aham pokkharasātissa  tārukkhassa ayam māṇavaḥ  tevijjānam yat akkhāta
translated: I’m Pokkharasāti’s student,
and this one is Tārukkha’s.🔽We’re experts in what’s taught by the masters of the three Vedas.
We’re skilled in the hymns and in the analysis of words,

original: Jappe ācariyasādisā.🔽Tesaṁ no jātivādasmiṁ,🔽vivādo atthi gotama;🔽Jātiyā brāhmaṇo hoti,
analyzed: jappe ācariya sādisā  naḥ jāti vādasmi  vivādaḥ atthi gotama  jātiyā brāhmaṇaḥ hoti
translated: and we’re teachers of the mantras.🔽We have a dispute with him about birth.
Bhāradvāja says that a brahmin is born from the womb of his mother,
while I say that a brahmin is made by his deeds.
Know this, O Gotama.”
We are unable to convince each other,
we both of us;
We have come to ask you,
the one renowned as the Buddha.

analyzed: candam yathā khayā atīta  pecca pañjalikā janā
translated: As people after the moon has set
with hands raised in salutation,🔽worship and revere it,
so do they the world’s Gotama.🔽We ask Gotama about the eye

analyzed: cakkhum loke samuppanna  mayam pucchāma gotama
translated: that has arisen in the world;
Is one a brahmin by birth,
or by action?
Please tell us who do not know,
so that we may know a brahmin.”
“I will explain to you,
(the Blessed One said to Vasettha)
in due course, as it really is;🔽The classification of beings
is different for each species.
Even grasses and trees
do not admit (that they are the same);
Their species is different,
the classification of beings.
Then insects and moths,
even down to ants and termites;
Their species is different,
the classification of beings.
Even among the four-footed
the small and the large;
Their species is different,
For the species are different.
Know that the snake and the lizard,
The long-bodied one and the worm,
Have their species-marks,
For the species are different.

analyzed: tatas mat śepi jānātha  ā udake vāri gocare
translated: Then know that the fish,🔽In the water, the domain of the waters,
Have their species-marks,
For the species are different.

analyzed: tatas pakkhīpi jānātha  patta yāne vihaṅgame
translated: Then know that the birds,🔽In the sky, the domain of the sky,
Have their species-marks,
For the species are different.

analyzed: yathā etāsu jātīsu  liṅgam jāti mayam puthu
translated: As in these species🔽The species-marks are various,

original: Evaṁ natthi manussesu,🔽Liṅgaṁ jātimayaṁ puthu.🔽Na kesehi na sīsena,
analyzed: evam na atthi manussesu  liṅgam jāti mayam puthu  na kesehi na sīsena
translated: So among human beings🔽There are no species-marks.
Not by the head, not by the hair,🔽Not by the ears, not by the eyes,
Not by the nose, not by the mouth,

original: Na oṭṭhehi bhamūhi vā.🔽Na gīvāya na aṁsehi,🔽Na udarena na piṭṭhiyā;
analyzed: na oṭṭhehi bhamūhi vā  na gīvāya na asehi  na udarena na piṭṭhiyā
translated: Not by the cheeks, not by the brows.🔽Not by the neck, not by the shoulders,🔽Not by the belly, not by the back,

original: Na soṇiyā na urasā,🔽Na sambādhe na methune.🔽Na hatthehi na pādehi,
analyzed: na soṇiyā na urasā  na sambādhe na methune  na hatthehi na pādehi
translated: Not by the genitals, not by the chest,🔽Not by the sides, not by the buttocks.🔽Not by the hands, not by the feet,

original: Nāṅgulīhi nakhehi vā;🔽Na jaṅghāhi na ūrūhi,🔽Na vaṇṇena sarena vā;
analyzed: na aṅgulīhi nakhehi vā  na jaṅghāhi na ūrūhi  na vaṇṇena sarena vā
translated: Not by the fingers, not by the nails,🔽Not by the calves, not by the thighs,🔽Not by the colour, not by the voice,
There is no species-mark
As in the other species.
And in the bodies of individuals,
This is not found among humans.
And the variation among humans,
Is spoken of by convention.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by protecting cattle,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a farmer, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by a separate craft,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a craftsman, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by trade,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a trader, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by being another’s servant,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a servant, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by taking what is not given,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a thief, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by the sword,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He is a soldier, not a brahmin.
Whoever among humans,
Subsists by the priesthood,
In this way, Vasettha, you should know,
He’s a sacrificer, not a brahmin.

original: Yo hi koci manussesu,🔽Gāmaṁ raṭṭhañca bhuñjati;
analyzed: yaḥ hi koci manussesu  gāmam raṭṭham ca bhuñjati
translated: Whoever enjoys a village or town,
Vāseṭṭha, know that he

original: Rājā eso na brāhmaṇo.🔽Na cāhaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ brūmi,
analyzed: rājā esaḥ na brāhmaṇaḥ  na ca aham brāhmaṇam brūmi
translated: is a king, not a brahmin.🔽I do not call a brahmin
one born of womb, descended from a clan,
who is called “sir,”

original: Sace hoti sakiñcano;🔽Akiñcanaṁ anādānaṁ,🔽Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
analyzed: sace hoti sakiñcanaḥ  akiñcanam an ādāna  tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa
translated: if he has possessions.🔽I call a brahmin🔽who is free from possessions, free from grasping,
who has cut off all fetters,
who is not agitated,

original: Saṅgātigaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ,🔽Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Chetvā naddhiṁ varattañca,🔽Sandānaṁ sahanukkamaṁ;
analyzed: saṅgātigam  tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  chetvā naddhim varattam ca  sandānam sahanukkama
translated: who has gone beyond all attachments,🔽who is detached,🔽who has removed the bolt and bar,
who is awakened,

original: Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Akkosaṁ vadhabandhañca,🔽Aduṭṭho yo titikkhati;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  akkosam vadha bandham ca  a duṭṭhaḥ yaḥ titikkhati
translated: I call a brahmin.🔽Who, unangered, endures
abuse, killing, and binding,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  akkodhanam vatavanta  sīlavantam anussada
translated: I call a brahmin.🔽Who is without anger, is well-spoken,🔽virtuous, and not arrogant,
tamed, with his last body,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  vāri pokkhara pattā iva  āraggeḥ iva sāsapaḥ
translated: I call a brahmin.🔽Who is unstained by sensual pleasures,
like a drop of water on a lotus leaf,🔽like a mustard seed on the point of an awl,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yaḥ dukkhassa pajānāti
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who understands right here
The destruction of suffering,
Who has laid down the burden, is unfettered,
I call him a brahmin.
One of deep wisdom, intelligent,
Skilled in what is the path and not the path,
Who has attained the supreme goal,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  a sasaṭṭham gahaṭṭhehi
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Not associating with householders
Or with those gone into homelessness,
Living alone, desiring little,
I call him a brahmin.
Having laid aside the rod against all beings,
Against the feeble and the strong,

analyzed: yaḥ na hanti na ghātā iti
translated: One who does not kill or get others to kill,
I call him a brahmin.

analyzed: a viruddham viruddhesu  atta daṇḍesu nibbuta
translated: Not opposing those who oppose,🔽Extinguished among those who wield weapons,
Not grasping at what is pleasing,

original: Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yassa rāgo ca doso ca,🔽Māno makkho ca pātito;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yassa rāgo ca doso ca  mānaḥ makkhaḥ ca pātito
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One in whom lust, hatred,
And conceit, contempt, and pride have fallen away,🔽Like a mountain peak that is unshaken,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  akakkasam viññāpani
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽One who speaks a word that is not harsh,
That is true and beneficial,
By which one would not accuse oneself,
I call him a brahmin.
One who does not do what is long or short,
The subtle and the gross, the beautiful and the ugly,
In this world he does not take what is not given,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.
For whom there are no expectations,
In this world and the next,
Free from expectations, detached,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.
For whom there are no abodes,
Having understood, he is not speculative,
Having attained the deathless state,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.
He who has gone beyond both merit and demerit,
The sorrowless, dust-free, pure one,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.🔽Like the spotless, pure moon,
Clear, unclouded,
With delight and existence destroyed,

original: Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yomaṁ palipathaṁ duggaṁ,🔽Saṁsāraṁ mohamaccagā;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yomam palipatham dugga  sasāram moham acca gā
translated: I call him a brāhmaṇa.🔽He who has crossed over this bog, this difficult place,
This round of births, delusion and darkness,🔽The meditator who has crossed over and gone beyond,
Without agitation, not speculative,
Extinguished through not grasping,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.
He who, having given up sense pleasures,
wanders homeless,
With sense-existence destroyed,
I call him a brāhmaṇa.
He who, having given up craving,
Who wanders homeless,
Who has destroyed craving and existence,
I call him a brahmin.
Having abandoned human bonds,
He has gone beyond divine bonds;
Who is released from all bonds,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  hitvā ratiñca a rati
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Having abandoned delight and displeasure,
Cooled off, without acquisitions,
The hero who has overcome the whole world,
I call him a brahmin.
Who knows the passing away of beings,
And their arising in every way,
The one without attachment, the well-gone, the enlightened one,
I call him a brahmin.
Whose destination is not known
By gods, gandhabbas, or humans,
The one with taints destroyed, the perfected one,

original: Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Yassa pure ca pacchā ca,🔽Majjhe ca natthi kiñcanaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  yassa pure ca pacchā ca  majjhe ca natthi kiñcana
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Who has nothing at all🔽In the past, future, or present,
The one without anything, the one without acquisitions,

original: Tamahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.🔽Usabhaṁ pavaraṁ vīraṁ,🔽Mahesiṁ vijitāvinaṁ;
analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  usabham pavaram vīra  mahā isim vijitāvina
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽The bull, the supreme hero,🔽The great seer, the conqueror,
The unshakable, the one who has bathed, the enlightened one,

analyzed: tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇa  pubbenivāsam yaḥ vedi
translated: I call him a brahmin.🔽Who remembers past abodes,
And sees heaven and the fall,
And who has reached the destruction of birth,
I call him a brahmin.
This is a convention in the world,
A name and clan proclaimed;
Agreed upon, come together,
Proclaimed here and there.
Long-standing, long-accumulated,
Not knowing the state of views;
Not knowing, they proclaim:

original: Jātiyā hoti brāhmaṇo.🔽Na jaccā brāhmaṇo hoti,
translated: ‘By birth one is a brahmin.’🔽Not by birth is one a brahmin,

original: Na jaccā hoti abrāhmaṇo;🔽Kammunā brāhmaṇo hoti,
translated: Not by birth is one not a brahmin;🔽By action one is a brahmin,

original: Kammunā hoti abrāhmaṇo.🔽Kassako kammunā hoti,🔽Sippiko hoti kammunā;
analyzed: kammunā hoti abrāhmaṇaḥ  kassakaḥ kammunā hoti  sippikaḥ hoti kammunā
translated: By action one is not a brahmin.🔽By action one is a farmer,🔽By action one is a craftsman;
By action one is a merchant,

original: Pessiko hoti kammunā.🔽Coropi kammunā hoti,🔽Yodhājīvopi kammunā;
analyzed: pessikaḥ hoti kammunā  coraḥ upi kammunā hoti  yodhājīvaḥ api kammunā
translated: By action one is a money-lender.🔽By action one is a thief,🔽By action one is a soldier;
By action one is a priest,
By action one is a king.
Thus this is as it really is,
The wise see action;
Seeing dependent origination,

analyzed: kamma vipāka kovidā  kammunā vattati lokaḥ
translated: Skilled in the ripening of action.🔽The world is set in motion by action,
The people are set in motion by action;
Beings are bound by action,
Like a wheel by the pin.
Through self-control and restraint,
By this one is a brahmin,
This is the highest brahmin.
Endowed with the three knowledges,
peaceful, with rebirth destroyed,
Thus, Vasettha, you should know
Brahma and Sakka as wise men.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte vāseṭṭha bhāradvājāḥ māṇavāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the brahmin students Vasettha and Bharadvaja said to the Blessed One:

“Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent, Master Gotama!🔽Master Gotama has made the Dhamma clear in many ways, as though he were turning upright what had been overthrown, revealing what was hidden, showing the way to one who is lost, or holding up a lamp in the dark for those with eyesight to see forms.🔽We go to Master Gotama for refuge and to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṁ gate”ti.
analyzed: upāsake naḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇam gatā iti
translated: Let Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone to him for refuge for life.”
The Ninth Sutta
